response.docs.abstract: Ronald Sanders, a writer who specialized in Jewish history and the immigrant experience in New York and elsewhere, died yesterday at his home in Manhattan. He was 58 years old.    He died of bone and liver cancer, his family said.   Mr. Sanders, a former editor of Midstream, the Zionist monthly journal, wrote extensively on Jews in Palestine and in the communities around the world to which they dispersed. He also dealt with the development of racism in America, which he traced to Columbian times.   His most popular book, "The Downtown Jews: Portrait of an Immigrant Generation," published by Harper & Row in 1970, detailed life on the Lower East Side beginning with the first wave of Russian Jewish arrivals in the 1880's. He paid particular attention to the cultural and ideological ferment that gave birth to a radical movement that fostered the formation of the International Ladies Garment Workers and other trade unions. A Demographic Contrast    In his most recent book, "Shores of Refuge: A Hundred Years of Jewish Emigration" (Henry Holt, 1988), Mr. Sanders provides an account of the population movement that has resulted in the fact that half the world's Jewish population lives in the Western Hemisphere, a stark contrast with the third quarter of the 19th century, when four of five Jews lived in Eastern and Central Europe.   In "Israel: The View From Masada," published in 1966, he offered an analysis of the cross-currents in that country's Jewish personality, notably the conflicts between Israelis with roots in central Europe and other Jews.    Mr. Sanders himself was half Jewish. He was born in Union City, N.J., to a Jewish mother and a gentile father, both immigrants from England, and grew up in Brooklyn. "Reflections on a Teapot," published in 1972, was a memoir inspired by a tune written by his father, George, a songwriter and arranger.   Mr. Sanders was a graduate of Kenyon College and held a master's degree in history from Columbia. He taught at Queens College in the late 1950's and early 1960's. In 1988 he was named to the B. G. Rudolph Chair in Jewish Studies at Syracuse University but was unable to accept it because of ill health.   His other books included "The High Walls of Jerusalem," a study of the Balfour Declaration of 1917 that pledged British support for a Jewish homeland in Palestine, and "The Days Grow Short," a biography of the composer Kurt Weill.     Before his final illness Mr. Sanders was working on a biography of the author Isaac Bashevis Singer, for which he had received a fellowship from the National Endowment for the Humanities.   He is survived by his wife, the former Beverly Gingold, and a sister, Marilyn O'Bradovich, of Manhattan.
response.docs.lead_paragraph: Ronald Sanders, a writer who specialized in Jewish history and the immigrant experience in New York and elsewhere, died yesterday at his home in Manhattan. He was 58 years old.
response.docs.headline.main: Ronald Sanders, 58, Who Wrote On Jewish History and Dispersal

response.docs.abstract: The Lebanese Government says it has arrested four senior Palestinian guerrillas, including a senior aide to the terrorist leader Abu Nidal, and is sending hundreds of troops to the south of the country in a bid to check the Palestine Liberation Organization's power there.   The Palestinians were seized on Tuesday after arriving at Beirut airport on forged passports. Among them was Walid Khalid, the spokesman for the breakaway Fatah Revolutionary Council, headed by Sabry al-Banna, who is better known by his code name, Abu Nidal. Mr. Khalid was arrested after arriving on a flight from Tunis, the Tunisian capital, with a forged Jordanian passport, the authorities said.

response.docs.abstract: Dorothy Silverstone, philanthropist and president emeritus of the International Cultural Center for Youth in Jerusalem, died on Saturday at her home in Manhattan. She was 89.   The cause was cardiac arrest, said her nephew, Paul Silverstone. - Mrs. Silverstone co-founded the Jerusalem center with her husband, the late Murray Silverstone, former president of 20th Century Fox International. Dedicated in 1960, the center was designed to be a place where Jewish and Arab children could learn about their own and other people's cultures.   On a visit to Israel in 1949, Mrs. Silverstone, aided by her three daughters, produced a film titled "The Magnetic Tide" about Jews and Arabs living together. The amateur film was distributed nationally by 20th Century Fox and the proceeds went to Children to Palestine, an interfaith group started to save Jewish children in Europe during World War II.
response.docs.lead_paragraph: Mrs. Silverstone co-founded the Jerusalem center with her husband, the late Murray Silverstone, former president of 20th Century Fox International. Dedicated in 1960, the center was designed to be a place where Jewish and Arab children could learn about their own and other people's cultures.

response.docs.abstract: Two Palestinians convicted of helping the hijackers of the Achille Lauro cruise ship have been released from prison early and expelled from Italy, their lawyer said today.   The men were identified as Issa Abbas, a cousin of the fugitive Palestine Liberation Front leader Abul Abbas, and Youssef Saad, said Gianfranco Pagano, the lawyer. He said they were released from prison on Christmas Eve under a law allowing a reduction of two years at Christmas season. The two departed for Algeria early in January, he said.   Leon Klinghoffer, a wheelchairbound American Jew who was a passenger on the liner, was shot to death by a hijacker and his body dumped into the Mediterranean during the October 1985 terrorist action.   Issa Abbas, a Syrian, was convicted of using a false passport in aiding the hijackers and sentenced to six months in prison in 1986. In a separate trial in November 1985, he had been convicted of smuggling the hijackers' weapons aboard and received a seven-year sentence.   Mr. Saad was convicted and sentenced to six years in prison in the 1986 trial for having imported money used to finance the hijacking.
response.docs.lead_paragraph: Two Palestinians convicted of helping the hijackers of the Achille Lauro cruise ship have been released from prison early and expelled from Italy, their lawyer said today.
response.docs.headline.main: Terrorists Get Early Release

response.docs.abstract: For three reasons, the election of Ezer Weizman as Israel's seventh President is welcome and interesting news. There is first the familial fact that his uncle was Chaim Weizmann (who spelled his name with two n's), the great Zionist and the first President of Israel -- a state he helped bring into being by persuading Britain, in the Balfour Declaration, to promise Jews a homeland.    Second is the political fact that the Israeli Parliament voted 66 to 53 for this man who advocates bolder approaches to peace with the Arabs, including direct negotiations with the Palestine Liberation Organization. His choice can only bolster Israeli moderates amid a discouraging impasse in Middle East peace talks. Although the office is mostly ceremonial, Mr. Weizman -- a former pilot and Defense Minister who helped fashion the Camp David accords with Egypt -- can speak with special credibility for a generous Zionist vision that views Palestinians not as permanent enemies but as potential friends.

He is still surrounded by a bit of mystery, largely because the 72-year-old physician has kept a low profile for nearly 30 years after starting out as an important organizer in the Palestinian movement. He is said to have been a Communist in his youth.

response.docs.abstract: Israeli troops today wounded as many as 55 Palestinians, including a 5-year-old girl, in the Gaza Strip's worst violence since the Persian Gulf war began in mid-January, Arab reports said.   The unrest came three days before a visit by Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d. An East Jerusalem Arabic newspaper, Al-Fajr, reported that the Palestine Liberation Organization had approved a meeting of local Palestinian leaders and Mr. Baker.    Palestinians in the Gaza Strip, the West Bank and East Jerusalem marked 39 months of revolt against Israeli occupation with a general strike.    The United Nations Relief and Works Agency said that Israeli troops shot and wounded 45 Palestinians in Rafah, in the Gaza Strip. And Arab hospital officials said 10 others, including the 5-year-old, were wounded in other towns. The Israeli Army said that only 20 Rafah residents and an officer and soldier had been hurt.
response.docs.lead_paragraph: Israeli troops today wounded as many as 55 Palestinians, including a 5-year-old girl, in the Gaza Strip's worst violence since the Persian Gulf war began in mid-January, Arab reports said.

response.docs.abstract: LEAD:  SYRIANS AND ALLIES  Syria, whose troops entered Lebanon in 1976, has about 40,000 soldiers there. They control about 70 percent of Lebanese territory. After initiallay seeking to curb Muslim factions, they began fighting Christian forces in later years.  The Lebanese Army's Muslim units are commanded by Maj.
response.docs.lead_paragraph: SYRIANS AND ALLIES Syria, whose troops entered Lebanon in 1976, has about 40,000 soldiers there. They control about 70 percent of Lebanese territory. After initiallay seeking to curb Muslim factions, they began fighting Christian forces in later years. The Lebanese Army's Muslim units are commanded by Maj. Gen. Sami Khatib and number about 22,000 Druse, Shiite and Sunni soldiers. The Druse militia of the Progressive Socialist Party, led by Walid Jumblat, numbers about 4,000 fighters, and has been fighting alongside the Syrians. The Druse community is an offshoot of Islam and its military base is in the Shuf mountains southeast of Beirut. The Party of God, a pro-Iranian Shiite militia and rival of Amal, has about 3,500 fighters. It controls Beirut's southern slums but has its main base in the Baalbek area of easters Lebanon. Supplied by Iran. it also received military training from 2,000 Revolutionary Guards sent into Lebanon from Iran in 1983. The Palestinians involved in the fighting, the Popular Front for the Liberation of Palestine, General Command, and the Fatah Uprising, consist of about 1,000 radical pro-Syrian dissidents out of the mainstream Palestine Liberation Organization of Yasir Arafat. The Popular Front Guerrillas are commanded by a former Syrian army captain, Ahmed Jabril, and those of the Fatah Uprising by Saed Musa. ANTI-SYRIAN FORCES The Lebanese Army's Christian units are commanded by Gen. Michel Aoun, a Maronite Catholic, and numbers about 20,000 soldiers, among whome the Maronites dominate. They are the main force defending the Christian districts in and around Beirut. The Lebanese Forces, the main Christian militia, is led by Samir Geagea. It numbers some 6,000 fighters, many trained and equipped by Israel. The South Lebanon Army is also backed by Israel, the army, mainly Christian, numbers about 2,500 fighters who, with 1,000 Israeli troops, patrol a 50-milke-long and 6-mile-deep area immediately north of the Israeli border that Israel calls its security zone.
response.docs.headline.main: Lebanon's Warring Factions
response.docs.headline.print_headline: Lebanon's Warring Factions

response.docs.abstract: LEAD: SHE IS KNOWN AS THE ''Mona Lisa of Roman Palestine.'' The portrait is part of a mosaic floor, dating to the third century - nearly 30 feet long and more than 20 feet wide - revealed in an excavation of the ancient city of Sepphoris, once the capital of Galilee, in what is now northern Israel. Discovered in August 1987 by an expedition led by two Duke University professors, Eric and Carol Meyers, and Ehud Netzer, an archaeologist at Hebrew University in Jerusalem, the mosaic was re-interred over the winter while financing was sought for its preservation.
response.docs.lead_paragraph: SHE IS KNOWN AS THE ''Mona Lisa of Roman Palestine.'' The portrait is part of a mosaic floor, dating to the third century - nearly 30 feet long and more than 20 feet wide - revealed in an excavation of the ancient city of Sepphoris, once the capital of Galilee, in what is now northern Israel. Discovered in August 1987 by an expedition led by two Duke University professors, Eric and Carol Meyers, and Ehud Netzer, an archaeologist at Hebrew University in Jerusalem, the mosaic was re-interred over the winter while financing was sought for its preservation. This summer, a fund established at Duke by the parents of an interested student has allowed the mosaic, composed of thousands of stone cubes, to be moved to the Israel Museum in Jerusalem, where it is to be exhibited this fall.
response.docs.headline.main: Those Eyes, That Smile

response.docs.abstract: LEAD: OPERATION BABYLON. By Shlomo Hillel. Translated by Ina Friedman. (Doubleday, $19.95.) From 1947 to 1952, approximately 125,000 Jews emigrated from Iraq - the oldest community in the Diaspora - to Israel. Shlomo Hillel, born in Iraq and today Speaker of Israel's Knesset, played a pivotal role in that exodus, working behind the lines first to ferry Jews out of the country clandestinely and then, after Iraq agreed to relax emigration restrictions briefly in 1950, to organize the airlift of nearly the entire remaining Jewish community.

response.docs.abstract: In the aftermath of large-scale clashes between rival factions within the Palestine Liberation Organization, 20 guerrillas who had participated in a mutiny against their commander were executed in southern Lebanon early today, security officials said. The deaths raised to 37 the number of people reported killed in the violence.   Close aides to a battalion commander in the main P.L.O. faction, Yasir Arafat's Fatah group, were tried by so-called revolutionary courts and condemned to death, the security officials said. The officials, who spoke on the condition that they not be further identified, said the aides had led an armed insurrection against the commander's superior officers.

response.docs.abstract:
American authorities have found it politically expedient to indict two Libyan intelligence officers for bombing Pan Am Flight 103 three years ago over Lockerbie, Scotland, rather than to pursue the real masterminds.

Although Abdel Basset Ali al-Megrahi and Lamen Khalifa Fhimah were charged on Thursday by British and American authorities with constructing and planting the bomb that killed 270 people, compelling evidence still suggests that Iran commissioned the bombing and with Syria's help paid Ahmed Jibril's terrorist organization, the Popular Front for the Liberation of Palestine, General Command, to carry it out.

response.docs.snippet: CAIRO - The British troops have made rapid advances in Mesopotamia on the way from Bagdad to Mossoul. General Marshall has advanced beyond Kerkouk, more than 164 miles from Bagdad. In consequence, however, of the difficulties of supplies in a regi...
response.docs.lead_paragraph: CAIRO - The British troops have made rapid advances in Mesopotamia on the way from Bagdad to Mossoul. General Marshall has advanced beyond Kerkouk, more than 164 miles from Bagdad. In consequence, however, of the difficulties of supplies in a region which does not possess roads, but only single tracks, the British line has been withdrawn behind Kerkouk. General Marshall's forces occupy the Tekritt region. In Palestine, all General Allenby's activity is directed against the Hedjaz railway, which supports the Turkish resistance and constitutes a menace to the right flank of the British army.

Others saw the vote as a political barometer, a victory for nationalism over religious fundamentalism.

response.docs.abstract: Nov. 29, 1947: The United Nations votes to recommend the partitioning of Palestine into three parts: a Jewish state, an Arab state and an international zone for the city of Jerusalem, administered by the United Nations. The Jews accept the recommendation; the Arabs reject it.   May, 15, 1948: As the old British mandate over Palestine from the League of Nations ends, the State of Israel is established and the United States is the first to recognize it. The same day, five Arab countries -- Egypt, Jordan, Iraq, Syria and Lebanon -- declare war and invade the new nation.

response.docs.abstract: A growing number of officials of the Palestine Liberation Organization, stunned by the damage to their movement from its support of Iraq in the Persian Gulf war, are openly calling for changes in the group's leadership and greater democracy in its decision-making process.    These officials say their aim is to dampen the role of hard-liners in the Palestinian leadership in exile -- in Tunisia, Syria, Iraq, Lebanon and elsewhere -- and to give Palestinians who are living under Israeli occupation in the West Bank and Gaza Strip a greater say in shaping future P.L.O. policies, including the terms of any settlement with Israel.

response.docs.abstract: If President Bush seriously wonders why Congress hasn't passed his crime bill in 100 days, he might refer to the bill's contents. Tucked away in its 166 pages is a section called "Terrorist Alien Removal," one of many proposals that Congress is wisely ignoring. It would create a flagrantly unjust system for deporting foreigners deemed to have terrorist connections -- using secret charges and secret evidence.    Consider how loose is the definition of "terrorist." An alien who raised money for the African National Congress or the Palestine Liberation Organization could be deported without seeing more than a bare outline of the charges, if the Justice Department wanted to call those organizations terrorist. Justice could make a secret arrest and secretly detain the alien while applying secretly for a court hearing.
response.docs.lead_paragraph: If President Bush seriously wonders why Congress hasn't passed his crime bill in 100 days, he might refer to the bill's contents. Tucked away in its 166 pages is a section called "Terrorist Alien Removal," one of many proposals that Congress is wisely ignoring. It would create a flagrantly unjust system for deporting foreigners deemed to have terrorist connections -- using secret charges and secret evidence.

response.docs.abstract: The question was startling, incongruous at first. "Do you think that Yasir Arafat will be the Palestinians' Ben-Gurion?" an aide to the Palestine Liberation Organization leader asked me in Tunis just before the Madrid conference opened.   The difference between the personalities of the leader who declared Israel's independence and the P.L.O.'s chairman is great. David Ben-Gurion was a decisive man, steeped in classical culture, straightforward and -- to Palestinians -- the enemy incarnate. Mr. Arafat is wily, certainly persistent and stubborn, gleefully adept at evasion.

response.docs.abstract: LONDON - [From our New York edition:] Dispatches from Ankara revealed that Britain closed the Syrian frontier opposite Turkey at 6 a.m. today [June 15], apparently to stop leakage of information concerning the British 9th and 10th Armies in the Middle Eas
response.docs.snippet: LONDON - [From our New York edition:] Dispatches from Ankara revealed that Britain closed the Syrian frontier opposite Turkey at 6 a.m. today [June 15], apparently to stop leakage of information concerning the British 9th and 10th Armies in the Mi...
response.docs.lead_paragraph: LONDON - [From our New York edition:] Dispatches from Ankara revealed that Britain closed the Syrian frontier opposite Turkey at 6 a.m. today [June 15], apparently to stop leakage of information concerning the British 9th and 10th Armies in the Middle East. The closing of the 400-mile frontier roused speculation that units of the two armies, which are stationed in Syria and Palestine, may be on the move. It was understood that German spies and intelligence operatives in Turkey were gathering information concerning British forces from Arabs entering Turkish territory through Syria. Closing the frontier was expected to shut down this fountainhead of espionage.

response.docs.abstract: President Saddam Hussein told a conference of Islamic leaders today that he was preparing for a holy war against the United States-led military alliance in the Persian Gulf that could only be averted if greater priority is given to solving the Palestinian problem.    In a half-hour speech given under tight security on the last day of the three-day Islamic session, Mr. Hussein spoke of war preparations, cleansing the Arab nation of corruption and of liberating Palestine. But he made no reference to the impending arrival here of the United Nations Secretary General, Javier Perez de Cuellar, seeking an 11th-hour commitment from Iraq to withdraw from Kuwait before a war that could break out in the region as early as Wednesday.

response.docs.abstract: IT is the ultimate cultural survivor in the Middle East: the plain or stitched cotton cloth that Arabs wear on their heads and draped down the back or shoulders. Designed more than 1,000 years ago, it originally protected against the harsh desert climate. Today, it's also an emblem of masculinity, maturity and nationalism. A substitute flag, a mask, a shield. A political or a fashion statement.   It is the kaffiyeh, the headdress, often tasseled, that has been adapted to a multitude of eras, having been embraced all over the Middle East by Muslims, Christians and Druse as well as by tourists and by<-- street vendors in Manhattan.

response.docs.abstract: Iraq acknowledged for the first time today that it was facing internal revolt but claimed a victory in the Persian Gulf war, saying President Bush's speech on the Middle East showed that Baghdad had forced the United States to focus on the Arab-Israel dispute.   After several days of uprisings in a string of southern Iraqi cities, Arab diplomats said Government troops appeared to have quelled street fighting in Basra, Iraq's second largest city and the heart of its Shiite Muslim south. President Saddam Hussein and his ruling establishment are drawn mostly from Sunni Muslim clans in the Takrit area north of Baghdad.

response.docs.abstract: Following are excerpts from an interview with President Sadam Hussein of Iraq, recorded Saturday and broadcast today by the French television network Antenne 2 and Radio France Inter. Mr. Hussein's comment, made in Arabic, were translated by The Associated Press from the French transcript provided by Antenne 2.   Q. Do you accept the dialogue proposed to you by President Bush?   A. If President Bush wishes to establish a balanced dialogue, such a dialogue must not get under way on the basis of preconditions. . . . President Bush has proposed two meetings. . . . We have accepted.   Q. What gesture are you ready to make to convince the world of your good will as you begin this dialogue?   A. There is no proposition more important than a dialogue that reaches a solution to all the problems of the region, and at their head the Palestinian problem. . . . We have taken a series of initiatives  [ regarding the hostages ] , and we have even fixed a date, March 25, as the last date for all of them to go home if nothing happens to disturb the peace.   This is not a tactic to sow discord in the ranks of whomever, but it is one of the means which we think are capable of preventing war. Such a method has perhaps proven its effectiveness, because so far there has been no war. . . .   We will free them . . . as soon as we have President Bush's assurance that he will not attack the Iraqi people between now and March 25. If after March 25, he still has the devil in his head, we will count on God to face any eventuality.  Our Face Is Saved     Q. Now that President Bush has proposed dialogue, and you can save face to an extent, why not open up some possibility regarding Kuwait?   A. Our face is saved. We don't need Bush for that. Our face is saved because we are believers. . . . You know that Bush has not taken the same measures vis-a-vis the Israeli occupation of Palestine and doesn't even lift his little finger when he sees on the television screens women, children and old people being killed, humiliated and tortured in Palestine by the Israelis.   The problem is that President Bush and the other Western heads of state have two United Nations charters . . . a criteria based on evaluations of their own needs and interests and a criteria for the oppressed peoples of the third world, oppressed by the policies of the Western bloc and by the United States in particular.   Q. Is it necessary for a country like Iraq to provide itself with a nuclear capability? The Americans say this will happen in a year or two.   A. I speak of the present. If we had nuclear weapons, we wouldn't have any problem saying so. . . . But we don't possess a nuclear weapon. . . . Why doesn't the West protest and worry at the destructive capabilities of Israel?   Q. And this evening, are we closer to war or to peace?   A. Fifty-fifty. If this meeting is to be a true path to dialogue, then we are closer to peace. But if this meeting is to be nothing more than a formal exhibition for the American Congress, the American people and for international public opinion, simply to salve consciences and say, "There, we've tried to talk to Iraq, without Iraq renouncing its position" -- in that case, we are closer to war.

Mr. Hussein's comment, made in Arabic, were translated by The Associated Press from the French transcript provided by Antenne 2.

response.docs.abstract:
THE PASSIONATE ATTACHMENT

America's Involvement With Israel,

response.docs.abstract: A gunman in Tunis shot and killed two of the highest-ranking leaders of the Palestine Liberation Organization late Monday night. The victims were among the closest and most influential aides to the P.L.O. chairman, Yasir Arafat.    The two men, who were shot to death about 11 P.M., were Saleh Khalef, known as Abu Iyad and widely acknowledged as Mr. Arafat's heir in Fatah, the mainline P.L.O. group, and Hayel Abdel-Hamid, known as Abu al-Hol, the chief of security of the guerrilla organization.

response.docs.abstract:
In preparing for a concert at Temple B'nai Or here entitled "From the Shtetl to Broadway," Deborah R. Staiman, the synagogue's cantor, searched for rarely heard songs and Jewish musical theater pieces.

"There's no need to be Jewish to attend this concert," she said emphatically. "This program is from a cultural point of view." The selections are theater music rather than liturgical piecs, she said. The concert involves cultural traditions and ways of life. She said it would be educational and informative.

response.docs.abstract:
When U.S. officials tried to convince Israel it should negotiate with the terrorist Palestine Liberation Organization, they vividly described its grip on the Arabs of Samaria, Judea and Gaza. We were told: "The P.L.O. is the main factor on the ground there. If you don't talk with the P.L.O. now, you'll soon have to talk with the fundamentalist Hamas gang." If this is the case when Israel is controlling these areas, imagine the situation if Israel relinquished them.

If Israel was out of Samaria, Judea and Gaza, the secular and Islamic fundamentalist terrorist groups would be in. And if they were in, a P.L.O.-Hamas terrorist state would be established -- something the U.S. and Israel could not tolerate. This is the reason the U.S. does not support establishment of an independent Arab state west of the Jordan River.

response.docs.abstract: Egyptian schoolchildren find Palestine, not Israel, on their maps in geography class. The destination of the flights to Tel Aviv, which require three hours of security checks, are not announced on information boards in the Cairo airport. And Egyptians who want to travel to Israel, numbering in the dozens, must spend months waiting for a separate passport and special Government permission.    But the decision by the Egyptian President to accept the invitation of the Israeli Prime Minister to visit Israel appears to have relaxed the strain that has characterized 13 years of distant relations. And it signals not only a change in the Egyptian attitude to Israel, but the Arab attitude toward Egypt.

response.docs.abstract:
If there is to be a chance for a regional peace initiative after the gulf war, Washington must make a determined effort to resolve the Palestinian problem. Diplomacy will falter anew if Washington, to avoid controversy with Jerusalem, tries to sidestep this central issue and moves instead toward direct talks between Israel and Syria. These would only divert the peace process.

In any negotiations, the Palestinians must be present if their claim to a homeland is at stake. Thus, the principal question is still the same: Who will speak for the Palestinians? The answer, as before, is the Palestine Liberation Organization.

response.docs.abstract: Saudi Arabia's Ambassador to the United States issued a warning today to Arab leaders who were sympathetic to Saddam Hussein that they must publicly recant.   The Ambassador, Prince Bandar bin Sultan, criticized King Hussein of Jordan, President Ali Abdullah Saleh, of Yemen, and Yasir Arafat of the Palestine Liberation Organization, all of whom were sympathetic to Mr. Hussein. "They must openly admit they were wrong," he said in an interview here. "We can't afford to sweep such things under the rug and pretend they didn't happen in the name of Arab unity, or the Arab masses will always be confused."
response.docs.lead_paragraph: Saudi Arabia's Ambassador to the United States issued a warning today to Arab leaders who were sympathetic to Saddam Hussein that they must publicly recant.

response.docs.abstract: Two weeks after deploying regular troops in the embattled south of the country, the Lebanese Government said today that it planned to press Israel to withdraw from the area it maintains as a "security zone" in the area, but a senior official in Israel served notice that his Government would not comply.   "Now that our army has established itself in southern Lebanon, we are ready to press on with our demand for implementing United Nations Security Council resolutions for Israeli evacuation," President Elias Hrawi was quoted in the local press as saying.    Security Council Resolution 425 called for a complete, unconditional Israeli pullout from the zone, 6 miles wide and 50 miles long, that the Israeli Army carved out five and a half years ago to guard against cross-border incursions by guerrillas.   Mr. Hrawi's statement coincided with the entry by Lebanese troops into the village of Milikh at the edge of the security zone.    An estimated 3,000 Lebanese troops have spread out east and south of the port city of Sidon 25 miles south of here after Palestinian and Lebanese Muslim guerrillas evacuated.    But the army deployment excluded Sidon and its suburbs, where thousands of Palestine Liberation Organization guerrillas are entrenched.    Uri Lubrani, Israel's coordinator of activity in southern Lebanon, said on the Israeli radio today that as long as the guerrillas were present north of the border, Israel would not give up its control of the zone.
response.docs.lead_paragraph: Two weeks after deploying regular troops in the embattled south of the country, the Lebanese Government said today that it planned to press Israel to withdraw from the area it maintains as a "security zone" in the area, but a senior official in Israel served notice that his Government would not comply.
response.docs.headline.main: Lebanon to Press for Israeli Pullout in South
response.docs.headline.print_headline: Lebanon to Press for Israeli Pullout in South

response.docs.lead_paragraph: The Soviet Union has announced that it will severely limit flights to Israel for emigrating Soviet Jews, and Yitzhak Shamir, the interim Prime Minister, held urgent meetings to find a way to counteract the Soviet decision. The Soviet announcement said that Aeroflot would no longer issue tickets to Soviet Jews planning to emigrate to Israel by flying through Hungary, a heavily used transit point. The Soviet announcement came as Yasir Arafat said in Casablanca, Morocco, that the Palestine Liberation Organization has asked Moscow to adopt specific measures to slow immigration of Soviet Jews to Israel.

response.docs.abstract: Asserting their intention to be treated as equals to everyone else at the conference table, Palestinian negotiators today gave the chief United States representative here a complete list of their delegates to the Middle East peace talks planned for Oct. 30 in Madrid.   The names of the Palestinian delegates are a critical issue because Israel has placed strict conditions on the Palestinians who will go to Madrid as part of a joint delegation with Jordan. Among other things, the Israelis rule out sitting down with anyone who is from East Jerusalem or has overt ties to the Palestine Liberation Organization.

response.docs.abstract: Under cover of a genuine war scare in Israel, Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir's right-wing coalition is promoting a spy scare that smells. Sari Nusseibeh, a prominent West Bank Palestinian, was arrested Tuesday for allegedly informing Iraqi targeters where Scud missiles had landed -- a grave charge if true. Mr. Nusseibeh, who denies doing any such thing, was given a six-month sentence without any trial or formal charges. That looks less like justice than a vendetta.    The day of his arrest, Mr. Nusseibeh met with Israeli supporters of Peace Now, a reputable group favoring territorial compromise with Palestinians. His Israeli visitors complained, justly, about the support to Iraq given by Yasir Arafat's Palestine Liberation Organization. According to Galia Golan, who was among the visitors, Mr. Nusseibeh promised to issue a statement condemning Iraq's use of terror missiles and reaffirming his support for a negotiated settlement between Palestinians and Israel. Hours later, he was in jail.
response.docs.lead_paragraph: Under cover of a genuine war scare in Israel, Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir's right-wing coalition is promoting a spy scare that smells. Sari Nusseibeh, a prominent West Bank Palestinian, was arrested Tuesday for allegedly informing Iraqi targeters where Scud missiles had landed -- a grave charge if true. Mr. Nusseibeh, who denies doing any such thing, was given a six-month sentence without any trial or formal charges. That looks less like justice than a vendetta.
response.docs.headline.main: Dubious Justice in Israel
response.docs.headline.print_headline: Dubious Justice in Israel

response.docs.abstract: LEAD: Polls now suggest that Israelis, who will vote this fall, favor the hard-line Likud bloc and Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir, adamant foes of any trade of land for peace. response.docs.lead_paragraph: Polls now suggest that Israelis, who will vote this fall, favor the hard-line Likud bloc and Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir, adamant foes of any trade of land for peace. But whatever the outcome, the Palestinian uprising in the West Bank and Gaza has fundamentally affected attitudes, even in Mr. Shamir's bloc. The assumption has been that the occupied territories might be pacified indefinitely without doing violence to Israel's principles. After six months of rebellion, and with more now promised by last week's Arab summit meeting, the election will test that assumption.
response.docs.headline.main: Even if Israel Budges, Then What?

response.docs.abstract: LEAD: WHEN Congress passed a law prohibiting anyone in the United States from operating an office on behalf of the Palestine Liberation Organization, its purpose seemed clear and simple. response.docs.lead_paragraph: WHEN Congress passed a law prohibiting anyone in the United States from operating an office on behalf of the Palestine Liberation Organization, its purpose seemed clear and simple. It wanted to close the P.L.O.'s observer mission to the United Nations because it had found the P.L.O. was a terrorist organization. But enforcement of the statute has proved much more complex, because it raises novel and delicate questions of constitutional and international law. The result has been a legal battle that could last for months.

response.docs.abstract: The pro-Western Arab countries appeared to lay down the law for new inter-Arab relations at an Arab League meeting here today, dismissing all of Iraq's justifications for occupying Kuwait and hinting that they no longer regard the Palestine Liberation Organization as the sole representative of Palestinians.   In restrained but purposeful speeches, the representatives of Egypt and Kuwait told delegates to the first full-fledged Arab League meeting in the aftermath of the Persian Gulf war that the Arab countries that participated in the defeat of Iraq, primarily Saudi Arabia, Egypt and Syria, will be the ones setting the Arab political agenda for some time to come.

response.docs.abstract:
Jesse Turner's wife and mother spent the day sitting with clasped hands on a living-room sofa awaiting news while surrounded by television cameras and reporters. They embraced tearfully tonight when word of the hostage's release came, then rushed to make preparations for leaving.

"I am positive now because of the United Nations announcement," said Mr. Turner's wife, Badr, 40 years old, who married him in 1986. Estelle Ronneburg, his 70-year-old mother, remained tense and subdued, hoping the good news was true.

The family planned to fly to Frankfurt, then head for a United States military hospital in Wiesbaden, Germany, where American hostages have generally been taken for medical tests after being freed in Lebanon.

Mrs. Ronneburg suffered severe disappointment when her son's photograph was released in April 1990 by his captors, the Islamic Holy War for the Liberation of Palestine, raising hopes that Mr. Turner would be freed. A few days later, the group instead freed Robert Polhill, who had been seized with Mr. Turner and Alann Steen in January 1987.

Mr. Turner's daughter, Joanna, who turned 4 years old in June, went to sleep tonight not knowing her father had been released.

She will be meeting him in Germany for the first time in her life: Joanna was born five months after he was abducted. She lived for nearly two years with her mother in Dubai, in the United Arab Emirates, before immigrating to America.
response.docs.snippet: Jesse Turner's wife and mother spent the day sitting with clasped hands on a living-room sofa awaiting news while surrounded by television cameras and reporters. They embraced tearfully tonight when word of the hostage's release came, then rushed ...
response.docs.lead_paragraph: Jesse Turner's wife and mother spent the day sitting with clasped hands on a living-room sofa awaiting news while surrounded by television cameras and reporters. They embraced tearfully tonight when word of the hostage's release came, then rushed to make preparations for leaving.
response.docs.headline.main:
AMERICAN HOSTAGE FREED IN LEBANON, U.N. OFFICIALS SAY;
A Family Waits

AMERICAN HOSTAGE FREED IN LEBANON, U.N. OFFICIALS SAY;

response.docs.abstract: On the first day of the war in the Persian Gulf, but before Iraqi missiles landed in Israel early this morning, the Arab world responded with mixed exuberance, relief and sorrow.    But the already overriding concern that Arabs might be losing control of their destiny to outside forces, and that the fighting will widen differences among Arabs, is likely to be compounded as the attack on Israel registers on people who for the most part were sleeping when it took place. Israel said it would retaliate against Iraq.

response.docs.abstract: Palestine Liberation Organization representatives and Arab diplomats who will take part in the Madrid peace conference agreed today that none of the Arab participants would make any separate deals with Israel. But they failed to endorse a Syrian proposal that would preclude Arab participation in regionwide talks on environmental and arms control issues until Israel had returned occupied Arab lands.   After two days of meetings here, the representatives from Lebanon, Jordan, Syria, Egypt and the P.L.O. agreed in a joint statement to "guarantee a unified Arab stand throughout all the phases of the conference and the talks that complement it."

response.docs.abstract: Tanks rolled through Kuwait City's Palestinian neighborhoods today as edgy Kuwaiti Army soldiers blocked off entire areas to make house-to-house searches for weapons and people who collaborated with the Iraqis. Other soldiers fired in the air as they walked down the main avenues.

response.docs.abstract: IN World War I, Britain drove the Ottomans out of the Middle East with the aid of both a Jewish Legion and Arab nationalists. The Jews were promised a homeland, the Arabs national states. The promises collided in Palestine, where the Arabs resisted an increasingly desperate Jewish migration; finally the British, in frustration, left it to the United Nations to partition the land. But the Arabs rejected the deal in 1948, launching the first of several wars in which they lost territory to Israel. This week, even though Israel has ruled out new territorial concessions, the land disputes left from the Israeli military triumphs of 1967 will be at the heart of the peace talks in Madrid. Here is an overview.

response.docs.abstract: THE MAN WHO THOUGHT HE WAS MESSIAH.  By Curt Leviant. (Jewish Publication Society, $18.95.) Hasidism appears profoundly conservative to modern eyes, but it was once a vibrant, radical, even revolutionary, movement. Breaking from the Judaism of the period, which they regarded as elitist, the Hasidic teachers of the 18th century sought to bring the gift of transcendence to the common man; through singing, dancing and fervent prayer, Hasidim aspired to mystical communion with God. Among the greatest of the Hasidic teachers was Rabbi Nachman of Bratslav, famous for the wisdom of his storytelling. In his enchanting, magical third novel, Curt Leviant becomes a modern Nachman and summons up a world suffused with a tangible spirituality, a world where trees or dreams or numbers might speak prophecy, where God is ever immanent behind the thin veil of the printed word. Sensual and intriguing, "The Man Who Thought He Was Messiah" shows us Reb Nachman in 1800, his incredibly eventful final year. It begins with God's whisper, a hint of Messianic destiny: Nachman might bring salvation to the scattered nation of Israel. Despite the presumption of this notion, Nachman seeks to prove himself worthy, but fails: he falls in love with Lizabeta, a young peasant "more beautiful than the alphabet." In fitting punishment, Nachman loses his ability to read; to atone for their liaison, he must leave Bratslav. Thus he travels to Vienna and studies composition with a proud but likable Beethoven; returning home with his new language of music, he finds his literacy partly restored. Setting out again, this time for the Holy Land, Nachman stops in Constantinople and, in a storybook scenario, cures the sultan's daughter of a storybook ailment. In Palestine divine tests await, and Nachman must probe his deepest values. Exquisitely written, Mr. Leviant's engaging exploration of the spirit will seduce and delight readers of any faith -- or lack thereof.

Sensual and intriguing, "The Man Who Thought He Was Messiah" shows us Reb Nachman in 1800, his incredibly eventful final year. It begins with God's whisper, a hint of Messianic destiny: Nachman might bring salvation to the scattered nation of Israel. Despite the presumption of this notion, Nachman seeks to prove himself worthy, but fails: he falls in love with Lizabeta, a young peasant "more beautiful than the alphabet." In fitting punishment, Nachman loses his ability to read; to atone for their liaison, he must leave Bratslav. Thus he travels to Vienna and studies composition with a proud but likable Beethoven; returning home with his new language of music, he finds his literacy partly restored. Setting out again, this time for the Holy Land, Nachman stops in Constantinople and, in a storybook scenario, cures the sultan's daughter of a storybook ailment. In Palestine divine tests await, and Nachman must probe his deepest values. Exquisitely written, Mr. Leviant's engaging exploration of the spirit will seduce and delight readers of any faith -- or lack thereof.

IN SHORT: FICTION;
Rabbi Nachman's Mystery Tour

response.docs.abstract: Christie's will auction a collection of world bank notes and artwork from the archives of the American Bank Note Company later this week. And what a strange collection it is. There are notes from Canada and Bolivia, from the Belgian Congo and Martinique. The American Bank Note Company was one of the largest printers of paper currency in the late 19th and early 20th centuries, so the variety of nations represented is not so surprising as are some of the notes' designs.   From the presses of this New York company were issued notes used by banks in most of the United States and all over the world. The American Bank Note Company was, in fact, the chief supplier for paper currency used by Canadian banks and even opened a subsidiary office in Ottawa in 1897. The company also became the main printer for Chinese bank notes from 1913 until 1949.

The Israelis until now have boycotted both forums because Palestinians living outside the West Bank and Gaza Strip have been allowed to take part.

response.docs.abstract: China's Foreign Minister was quoted today as saying that China and Israel were on course toward an eventual establishment of diplomatic relations, but the pace of progress seemed likely to depend on the Arab-Israeli peace process.   China, the only one of the five permanent members of the United Nations Security Council not to recognize Israel, has good relations with Arab countries but has moved slowly in recent years to develop ties with Israel. Some Chinese officials believe that after establishment of relations, China would be able to play a role in Middle East peace negotiations.

response.docs.abstract: Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d and President Hafez al-Assad of Syria held more than six hours of talks tonight about how to promote Arab-Israeli peace talks in the wake of the Persian Gulf war.   Mr. Baker and Mr. Assad began their talks about 5:20 P.M. Damascus time and were still talking at 11:20 P.M., when American officials emerged to tell reporters that the two men intended to continue into the night and were canceling a previously scheduled news conference. It was rescheduled for Thursday, before Mr. Baker leaves for Moscow.

response.docs.abstract: Yitzhak Shamir is an improbable leader, a man of monumental caution who nonetheless spent much of his adult life taking risks, a pragmatist who nonetheless speaks with an ideologue's fervor about the right of Jews to populate all of the biblical Land of Israel.    When he became Prime Minister after Menachem Begin's sudden resignation in 1983, Mr. Shamir was supposed to serve as a caretaker until a stronger figure could be found. Yet except for two years when the prime ministership went elsewhere, he has presided over the Government ever since, serving longer than any Israeli leader except David Ben-Gurion.

response.docs.abstract: The United States secured another delay tonight in a vote on a controversial Security Council resolution that it believes President Saddam Hussein would interpret as a sign of weakness.   The adjournment of the talks until Monday gives the United States more time to seek changes in the proposed resolution, which now seeks to give United Nations protection to Palestinians living in the Israeli-occupied territories. The draft measure also endorses a plan to convene an international Middle East peace conference to resolve the region's problems at an unspecified future date.

response.docs.lead_paragraph: To contemplate the prospects for an Israeli-Palestinian peace is to sink into sadness. Every avenue to negotiations seems too complicated or too risky. response.docs.abstract: Hundreds of books and articles about Israel keep appearing each year, analyzing and reanalyzing its foreign policy and internal politics from every conceivable point of view. But very little has been written about Israel's culture, and it remains a mystery, except perhaps to Israel itself.   Yet a national culture is developing there, one that is in constant tension with the literature and values of the classic past. So, for example, the poet Yehuda Amichai keeps struggling, line by line, to write about everyday life in spare, modern Hebrew, but he knows that almost every one of the words has a history that goes back to the Bible. The contemporary life that he lives amid the stones of ancient Jerusalem, and the very words that he uses to describe that life, cannot be bound by the past, or escape from it.
response.docs.lead_paragraph: Hundreds of books and articles about Israel keep appearing each year, analyzing and reanalyzing its foreign policy and internal politics from every conceivable point of view. But very little has been written about Israel's culture, and it remains a mystery, except perhaps to Israel itself.
response.docs.headline.main: 100 Years Later, a Jewish Writer's Time Has Come
response.docs.headline.print_headline: 100 Years Later, a Jewish Writer's Time Has Come

response.docs.abstract: The opening of the Madrid peace conference was greeted in the Middle East today with new bloodshed and calls for an Islamic holy war against Israel, but also with a rare peace march by supporters of the Palestine Liberation Organization.    One Palestinian youth was shot to death and at least 35 others were wounded in stone-throwing clashes with the Israeli Army in the West Bank and Gaza Strip. It was an uncommonly high casualty count even for people grown numb to the incessant mayhem produced by the four-year-old Palestinian uprising against Israeli occupation.

response.docs.abstract: The Blue Mountain By Meir Shalev Translated by Hillel Halkin. 375 pages. Aaron Asher Books/HarperCollins. $22.95.   In "The Blue Mountain," Meir Shalev uses fictional characters and folkloric wisdom to depict the pioneering life of Jewish families thrown together in a small cooperative village decades before the birth of the State of Israel. The villagers have gladly traded one hardship for another: the fear of living almost as aliens in their native Russia for an alien wilderness in Palestine. The untamed land these settlers inhabit before and after World War I stands in marked contrast to the developed country encountered by the recent arrivals from the Soviet Union. The stubborn characters in Mr. Shalev's novel may well remind readers of some of the tough-minded old-timers with similar backgrounds in modern Israel.

response.docs.abstract: LEAD: A century or so ago, when idealistic Zionists in Europe talked of returning to Palestine, it must have seemed as though they were nurturing an utterly impossible dream. One never knows, however, how things will turn out, which is one of the reasons hope springs eternal. A Swedish-made documentary, filmed in part in the shadow of Mount Ararat, the geographical and spiritual center of the Armenian homeland destroyed by the Turks during World War I, seems aimed at keeping the flame of hope alive.
response.docs.lead_paragraph: A century or so ago, when idealistic Zionists in Europe talked of returning to Palestine, it must have seemed as though they were nurturing an utterly impossible dream. One never knows, however, how things will turn out, which is one of the reasons hope springs eternal. A Swedish-made documentary, filmed in part in the shadow of Mount Ararat, the geographical and spiritual center of the Armenian homeland destroyed by the Turks during World War I, seems aimed at keeping the flame of hope alive. It returns frequently to the theme of an empty land waiting for the return of its people. And yet the very evidence the film presents shows just how dim the flame is.
response.docs.headline.main: Review/Film; Armenian Homeland: A Flickering Flame
response.docs.headline.print_headline: Review/Film; Armenian Homeland: A Flickering Flame

response.docs.abstract: As Iraqis danced in the streets of Baghdad in response to President Saddam Hussein's speech ordering a withdrawal from Kuwait, Palestinians and Jordanians, who had been his ardent supporters, seemed stunned, bewildered and enraged today.   Those turbulent emotions were quickly fused into a general anger transferred to the Americans seen as the architects of his, and their, humiliation.   "You Americans, you are all liars," said a Jordanian officer who displayed increasing bewilderment, then hostility, as he listened to the speech with Western reporters at the Ruweishid border crossing into Iraq.   Many in Amman at first refused to believe the news, telephoning international news agencies to inquire whether it was not some kind of hoax. In their heart of hearts, many had known that the Iraqi leader could not prevail. What hurt was the speed of his collapse. Baghdad Radio's Message     When Iraq invaded Kuwait on Aug. 2, President Hussein quickly linked his action to the Israeli-Palestinian conflict, insisting that a pullout be linked to an Israeli withdrawal from occupied Arab lands.   "It looked like Gamal Abdel Nasser coming back," said Nabil Shaath, a senior adviser to Yasir Arafat, the leader of the Palestine Liberation Organization. "It looked like a knight with shining armor, the hero fighting the Americans."   For the six weeks of the war, a Western specialist said, Palestinians had chosen to believe the central message of the Baghdad radio's propaganda: allied airplanes might prowl the skies, but Iraq's ground forces, tested in the 1980-88 Iran-Iraq war, had the skills to resist an allied offensive.   Then, two days after allied troops pressed forward into Kuwait, Iraq announced its withdrawal. 'Longer Fight' Expected     Reached by telephone in Cairo, Mr. Shaath said that eventually President Hussein's move "will be seen as a very prudent move." But, he acknowledged, "people expected a longer fight."
response.docs.lead_paragraph: As Iraqis danced in the streets of Baghdad in response to President Saddam Hussein's speech ordering a withdrawal from Kuwait, Palestinians and Jordanians, who had been his ardent supporters, seemed stunned, bewildered and enraged today.
response.docs.headline.main: Dominant Emotion: Anger at the U.S.
response.docs.headline.kicker: WAR IN THE GULF: WORLD REACTION - ARABS
response.docs.headline.print_headline: WAR IN THE GULF: WORLD REACTION - ARABS; Dominant Emotion: Anger at the U.S.

response.docs.abstract: What a welcome irony looms on the Mideast horizon: It's just possible that Saddam Hussein gave an unintended boost to Arab-Israeli peace. His Scud attacks, meant to incite Israel and win back Arab support, did neither. And his aggression drove Syria, Saudi Arabia and Egypt closer to the U.S. The man who tried to barter Kuwait for Palestine and spur an Arab crusade against Israel has revitalized diplomacy.    The starting point for diplomacy is U.N. Security Council Resolution 242 of 1967, and its sequel, No. 338 of 1973. These call for Israel's withdrawal from occupied territories in exchange for Arab recognition of its sovereignty, territorial integrity and right to secure boundaries. Mr. Bush reaffirmed the importance of the resolutions last week.
response.docs.lead_paragraph: What a welcome irony looms on the Mideast horizon: It's just possible that Saddam Hussein gave an unintended boost to Arab-Israeli peace. His Scud attacks, meant to incite Israel and win back Arab support, did neither. response.docs.abstract: The conductor Daniel Barenboim is right to try to break an Israeli taboo about performing the music of Richard Wagner. Nobody will be compelled to attend or listen next week when his orchestra, the Israel Philharmonic, plays its first Wagner concert since 1938, when it was the Palestine Philharmonic. "What we are talking about," says Mr. Barenboim, "is a simple issue of free expression in a democratic society."    Yet his indignant critics are also right on one large point. Wagner, who died in 1883, was zealously anti-Semitic, and his descendants all too eagerly allowed Hitler to turn Bayreuth, Wagner's home, into a shrine for a criminal creed.

response.docs.abstract: Iraqi television tonight broadcast a videotape of what was described as President Saddam Hussein's visit on Monday night to his front-line forces in Kuwait, where he gave them a pep talk, stirred their campfire meals and pronounced them "ready to fight."    The New Year's Eve visit to the front was not announced in advance and the videotape was made public tonight without explanation about the delay. Mr. Hussein was videotaped outdoors meeting with troops bivouacked in the desert. He then delivered remarks indoors to a group of officers described as Iraqi commanders in Kuwait.

response.docs.abstract: In salvos of intransigent oratory, Israel and its Arab neighbors said today that they all hoped to end the bloodshed in their region, but disagreed about almost everything else -- who was at fault, what to do about it, even where further peace talks should be held.    On a day when the Palestinians at last found their place at a major Middle East peace conference, the Arabs demanded that Israel stop creating settlements in occupied territories and give up territory it had taken from Arabs in 1967. The Israelis in turn demanded that the Arabs recognize Israel's right to exist.
response.docs.lead_paragraph: In salvos of intransigent oratory, Israel and its Arab neighbors said today that they all hoped to end the bloodshed in their region, but disagreed about almost everything else -- who was at fault, what to do about it, even where further peace talks should be held.
