response.docs.abstract: LEAD: ''Voyage of Terror: The Achille Lauro Affair'' is the second television movie based on the 1985 hijacking by four Palestinians of an Italian cruise ship in the Mediterranean. This one, starring Burt Lancaster and Eva-Marie Saint as the American passengers Leon and Marilyn Klinghoffer, makes its own special claims to authenticity.
response.docs.lead_paragraph: ''Voyage of Terror: The Achille Lauro Affair'' is the second television movie based on the 1985 hijacking by four Palestinians of an Italian cruise ship in the Mediterranean. This one, starring Burt Lancaster and Eva-Marie Saint as the American passengers Leon and Marilyn Klinghoffer, makes its own special claims to authenticity. Actually filmed aboard the Achille Lauro, it retraces the ship's route from Genoa, Italy, to Alexandria and Port Said, Egypt. Gerardo De Rosa, the ship's captain at the time of the hijacking, served as consultant.

response.docs.abstract: As Secretary of State James Baker meets the Iraqi Foreign Minister, Tariq Aziz, hopes rise that the talks will amount to more than a repetition of the public postures of the two sides. In an era suspicious of secrecy, millions wish devoutly for a hidden agenda today in Geneva.   Yet, while the timetable clicks on inexorably in the Persian Gulf, there is a gathering sense of irrelevance about the stark options to which Washington is reduced. Neither war nor a last-minute diplomatic device will resolve the deeper issues that have brought us to this bleak rendezvous in the desert. Whatever the outcome in Geneva, the Administration's choices between battle and backdown betray an underlying futility -- and thus carry the seeds of future crisis.
response.docs.lead_paragraph: As Secretary of State James Baker meets the Iraqi Foreign Minister, Tariq Aziz, hopes rise that the talks will amount to more than a repetition of the public postures of the two sides. In an era suspicious of secrecy, millions wish devoutly for a hidden agenda today in Geneva.
response.docs.headline.main: Why War Is Irrelevant

response.docs.abstract: In a much-awaited decision carrying immediate implications for Israel's diplomatic standing and for the future of the Middle East peace talks, the Israeli High Court of Justice today unanimously validated the deportation of more than 400 Palestinians from the occupied territories to Lebanon.    Although the seven justices expressed reservations about some aspects of the Government action, they declared the mid-December mass expulsions to be legitimate and rejected appeals to bring the Palestinians back.

response.docs.abstract: In a day of intense diplomatic maneuvering that finally brought Israel into separate and direct talks with its Arab neighbors, the Israelis and Palestinians announced today that they would soon begin negotiations on self-rule for the West Bank and Gaza Strip, which are occupied by Israel.   The session in an ornate palace here, held after decades of war and hatred in the Middle East, was the first time the Israelis had openly met with a Palestinian group that publicly said it represented Palestinian national aspirations. It was also the first time Israel had met with the Syrians, who regard Israel as their sworn enemy.
response.docs.lead_paragraph: In a day of intense diplomatic maneuvering that finally brought Israel into separate and direct talks with its Arab neighbors, the Israelis and Palestinians announced today that they would soon begin negotiations on self-rule for the West Bank and Gaza Strip, which are occupied by Israel.

response.docs.abstract: WHO would have thought it? After five months of staring one another in the eye, George Bush blinked and Saddam Hussein blinked right back.   O.K., maybe it was more a fluttering of eyelids than full-fledged blinking, but Mr. Bush's offer to send Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d to Geneva next Wednesday, and the Iraqis' decision to meet with the Americans on their terms, represents some subtle compromising by both sides. The meeting date, Jan. 9, is well after the Jan. 3 deadline President Bush had previously imposed for any dialogue, and before the Jan. 12 date previously demanded by Baghdad. It is hardly the stuff of unconditional surrender, and this agreement on a date for talks may be as close to a negotiation as the two sides come. But for the time being at least, both Baghdad and Washington are going to find themselves under wholly different pressures than they were when no dialogue was in sight.
response.docs.lead_paragraph: WHO would have thought it? After five months of staring one another in the eye, George Bush blinked and Saddam Hussein blinked right back.
response.docs.headline.main: Hello, Baghdad; Agreeing to Meet Puts New Pressure On U.S. and Iraq

response.docs.abstract: If there's a living soul who embodies the city of Jerusalem, it's Teddy Kollek. This is a lament for the city, and for him, because he has made his life's work trying to revive it, beautify it and bring it harmony.   But it has wrenched itself apart in fear, hatred and violence. Not that Teddy weeps; it isn't his way. He still storms around, tongue-lashing the arrogant and the fanatic, crowing delight at the greenery, the great art and music brought to give warmth to the old stones and the hopes they symbolize.   Teddy -- everyone calls him that -- has been Mayor since 1965. When he was first elected, there was a high tin wall next to his office in the Municipal Building, a shield to protect people in the streets from snipers on the Old City walls nearby.   After the 1967 war, all the physical barriers were torn down. Teddy plunged into ceaseless activity to unite the city, if not in friendship -- that was too much to ask -- at least in mutual acceptance and neighborliness.   For a long time, Jerusalem was a virtual island of calm as waves of bloody anger rose around it. That was not by happenstance. Teddy, who is known for falling asleep on public occasions, habitually spent only three or four hours a night in bed so he could look after the hospitals and schools and parks he was building, visit all kinds of people, deliver his message of good will and try to make amends for provocation.   It wasn't surprising that when the Government of Israel refused to receive a United Nations delegation after the recent killings on the Temple Mount, Teddy's was the one voice saying he would be glad to see anyone who wanted to talk to him. His is a voice of reason. "The world is a better place when moderates run it," he has said.   He was born in Vienna in 1911 and joined a Zionist youth group as a teen-ager. He undertook clandestine missions around Europe to help save Jews from Hitler, settling in Palestine in 1935 as a pioneer. As an aide to David Ben-Gurion, who became Israel's first Prime Minister when the state was founded in 1948, he was closely involved in the dreams and pains of its creation.   He never did well in national politics. He is too blunt, too demanding and straightforward, too attentive to the details of everyday human troubles to get on with the party apparatus, as Israel's unwieldy system requires for advancement. But the same qualities brought him such personal admiration and affection that he has always been re-elected Mayor.   It was not without constant quarrels. Nationalists say he does too much for Arabs. He bemoans constraints on attending to their needs as fellow citizens. Worried about youth gangs, he multiplied diversions -- festivals, sports to keep young people busy. But when he wanted to build a municipal swimming pool, he was called "too Hellenistic."   Still, it worked for a time. As late as last year, only one Palestinian had been killed in Jerusalem while hundreds died in the occupied territories, and the police had never fired live ammunition at rioters. Now the toll is mounting.   The ranks of die-hard fundamentalists are growing on both sides. Meron Benvenisti, his former Deputy Mayor who parted ways with his boss years ago over Teddy's insistence on looking at the bright side, has called him "a hero in a tragedy."   But he also pointed out, "Jerusalem isn't a piece of real estate, it's a symbol for both sides, and symbols are indivisible and exclusive. The Palestinians aren't looking for good government, they're after a political identity, self-esteem, their own flag. If you think they'll settle for better sewers and roads, you're mad."   Teddy refuses to despair. Undermined, saddened, he seeks reason for consolation. From the telephone in his car as he raced about, he told me: "It's been a bad few weeks. But fewer people have been killed in Jerusalem than in other cities this size. I hear  [ New York's ]  Mayor Dinkins is talking about a curfew to control crime. Of course it's different; here it's nationalism and there it's crime."   He's still finding practical ways to improve the city's life on both sides of the emotional divide. There's no question, he said, of a big new settlement for Soviet immigrants in East Jerusalem, as the Israeli Government suggested. He's planning 7,000 new apartments for Arab housing.   "We're all in a bad mood now. But we all know there's no choice, we'll be together forever. Wait a few weeks until it simmers down, before we can talk and make sense."   But it isn't going that way. Teddy will be 80 in May. "It's a different generation, they aren't heard," another Israeli commented. Not only the story of Teddy's life will seem vain if another generation fails to join his endless work for a Jerusalem at peace.
response.docs.lead_paragraph: If there's a living soul who embodies the city of Jerusalem, it's Teddy Kollek. This is a lament for the city, and for him, because he has made his life's work trying to revive it, beautify it and bring it harmony.
response.docs.headline.main: Lament for Jerusalem
response.docs.headline.print_headline: FOREIGN AFFAIRS; Lament for Jerusalem
response.docs.headline.name: NA

response.docs.abstract: LEAD: President Bush dropped the longstanding American opposition to Soviet involvement in Middle East peace efforts during his meeting with President Mikhail S. Gorbachev on Sunday, Administration officials confirmed today.
response.docs.lead_paragraph: The first sign of this change was given at the Gorbachev-Bush news conference in Helsinki on Sunday when Mr. Gorbachev said he had a ''secret'' to reveal - that Mr. Bush had confessed that in the past the United States had tried to keep the Soviet Union out of the Middle East but that now he felt that it was important to cooperate. Was Israel Consulted? The officials today called this aspect of the meeting, which was reflected in comments by Mr. Gorbachev and in the two leaders' joint statement, a development that was overshadowed by the two leaders' vow to oppose Baghdad in the immediate crisis and by their apparent divisions over the use of military force.
response.docs.headline.main: BUSH, REVERSING U.S. POLICY, WON'T OPPOSE A SOVIET ROLE IN MIDDLE EAST PEACE TALKS
response.docs.headline.print_headline: CONFRONTATION IN THE GULF;   BUSH, REVERSING U.S. POLICY, WON'T OPPOSE A SOVIET ROLE IN MIDDLE EAST PEACE TALKS

response.docs.abstract: As the Persian Gulf war grew more complex, one of the most hectic weeks in Wall Street history ended yesterday with a last-minute flurry that carried the Dow Jones industrial average ahead 23.27 points.   The gain, the fourth in a row and in spite of an Iraqi missile attack on Israel early yesterday morning, brought the Dow to 2,646.78. For the week, the bellwether index added 145.29 points, or 5.8 percent, the biggest weekly point gain in history. The previous biggest point gain came in the week ended Oct. 19, 1990, when the Dow jumped 122.77 points, partly on signs that Iraq was seeking a peaceful settlement to the gulf crisis.   This week's gain in percentage terms was just short of a 5.9 percent rise in June 1988, when interest rates appeared to be declining.  Late Burst of Trading     Volume was strong yesterday, with 226.8 million shares traded, a third in the final hour. Traders attributed the late activity to a call by an Iraqi official for "genuine negotiation."   The day before, amid euphoria that allied military forces seemed headed for a quick victory over Iraq, harried traders strained under a flood of buy orders that lifted trading to 318.9 million shares.    It was the heaviest trading flow since the Monday after the October plunge of 1989.    Yesterday's increase went far beyond the Dow blue chips. The Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks climbed 1.3 percent. On the Big Board, 21 stocks rose to new highs, 836 advanced and 678 declined. Still, 32 stocks dropped to new lows.    "Everybody thought the market would drop after Iraq attacked Israel," said William M. LeFevre, market strategist for Advest Inc. "But when it didn't drop very much at the opening and crude oil kept going down, up went stocks to the highest level since mid-August." Crude oil fell $2.19, to $19.25 a barrel.    In a more candid assessment, Donald Tierney, metals analyst for Fortune Commodities, told the Dow Jones news service that "headline trading" drove the market.    Minute after minute, news tickers reported every scrap of information and rumor from the war. Much of it dealt with Israel: whether it would retaliate against Iraq, that sirens were going off in Israel and Saudi Arabia, that the Pentagon doubted that Iraq had fired more missiles, that President Saddam Hussein had sent his family out of the country.    At 2 P.M., two hours before the close, the Dow stood at roughly 2,620 -- about where it ended the day before.    But at 3:17, the ticker carried a Cable News Network interview with Iraq's Ambassador to the United Nations, Abdul Amir al-Anbari, in which he called on President Bush to try "genuine negotiation" to end the war.    "There's no problem that cannot be solved peacefully," he said.    Within minutes, the Dow was ahead nearly 30 points, fell back a little, rose slightly again, and again fell back.    The Ambassador linked the negotiations to the Palestine question, a position the Administration has rejected. The Dow, however, held most of its gain.  Move by Program Traders    The news came a few minutes after program traders moved heavily into the market, driving the Dow 15 points higher. Further waves of program buying raised the Dow 38 points, Birinyi Associates said.    While the Dow was up 20 points earlier in the day, one trader said, tickers reported that a new volley of missiles had been fired at Israel, immediately bringing the index down sharply. The report was later discredited.    Still earlier rumors circulated that President Hussein had been shot by one of his generals. That was also denied, but the rumor, coming at a time the Dow was down a few points, pushed the Dow up 15.  Up and Down Swings    Every turn in the market brought much the same. Good news prompted traders to buy technology stocks, motor stocks and drug, food, beverage and tobacco issues. Bad news reversed the process and investors, speculators and traders unloaded what they had just bought.    In one of the clearest signs that Wall Street fears seemed to have lightened, people told jokes again.    "All through this week," a trader remarked, "nobody's been telling jokes because things are too serious. But because the war seems to be going our way, people are trying to lighten up the situation."    CNA Financial, controlled by the Tisch family, soared 8 3/4, to 78 1/2, in a strong insurance group after rising 5 3/4 Thursday. A short war would be favorable to insurers in that it would lessen deterioration of real estate assets. AIG, an insurance industry leader, jumped 3, to 80.
response.docs.lead_paragraph: As the Persian Gulf war grew more complex, one of the most hectic weeks in Wall Street history ended yesterday with a last-minute flurry that carried the Dow Jones industrial average ahead 23.27 points.
response.docs.headline.main: Dow Rises; Week's Gain Sets Record
response.docs.headline.print_headline: Dow Rises; Week's Gain Sets Record

response.docs.abstract:
"I understand why 'they' do it," a friend wrote me from Jerusalem, "and I suppose I understand why 'we' do it. And there is nothing left for me to do." An American by birth, she and her Israeli husband have been active in the peace movement for 20 years. She had spent a Saturday afternoon protesting the killing of 19 Palestinians by Israeli police on the Temple Mount. That Sunday morning an Arab youth knifed three Israelis to death blocks from her home. She confessed, "I feel a terror such as I've never known before."

And now Rabbi Meir Kahane has been murdered in New York City -- just as his raging, tribal, romantically militant vision of Zion is on the verge of being realized. His death will not come as a relief to my friend. But it affords a dramatic opportunity for Americans to grasp what she feels, that Rabbi Kahane's politics -- and the politics of Palestinian extremists -- have overwhelmed political movements for democratic co-existence.

response.docs.abstract: LEAD: Israel's Prime Minister, Yitzhak Shamir, has presented a plan for Israeli-supervised elections in the occupied territories. The elections would produce Palestinian representatives who would negotiate with Israel on interim autonomy for the West Bank and Gaza Strip. He did not address what, if anything, might follow the interim arrangement.
response.docs.lead_paragraph: Israel's Prime Minister, Yitzhak Shamir, has presented a plan for Israeli-supervised elections in the occupied territories. The elections would produce Palestinian representatives who would negotiate with Israel on interim autonomy for the West Bank and Gaza Strip. He did not address what, if anything, might follow the interim arrangement. Israel's Foreign Minister, Moshe Arens, said later that the interim period would serve as a ''test of cooperation and co-existence.'' It would be ''followed by negotiations on the final settlement, in which Israel will be prepared to discuss any option.''
response.docs.headline.main: Arafat: Yes and No to Elections

response.docs.abstract: LEAD: OBVIOUSLY, A LONGSTANDING conflict like that between the Israelis and the Palestinians can be resolved any number of ways - particularly when one side has the power to impose a settlement on the other. The question here, however, is not about a so-called ''agreement'' that one side forces the other to accept, but a true, lasting settlement that elicits a reasonable degree of consent from both.
response.docs.lead_paragraph: OBVIOUSLY, A LONGSTANDING conflict like that between the Israelis and the Palestinians can be resolved any number of ways - particularly when one side has the power to impose a settlement on the other. The question here, however, is not about a so-called ''agreement'' that one side forces the other to accept, but a true, lasting settlement that elicits a reasonable degree of consent from both. Briefly, is there a political prescription that can be given to Palestinians and Israelis that will encourage them to take part - willingly - in a process that will truly bring their conflict to an end?
response.docs.headline.main: A Palestinian View

response.docs.abstract: Palestinian and Jordanian negotiators finally arrived in Washington today for the next round of Middle East peace talks. At the same time, the Bush Administration sought to defuse a dispute brewing over its recent backing of a United Nations resolution that appeared to support Palestinian claims to the West Bank and Jerusalem.   Israeli negotiators, who have been in Washington since Sunday, say they are ready to resume the negotiations immediately because they intend to leave Washington by Jan. 15. Arab delegates have been saying that they don't expect to begin before Sunday.

response.docs.abstract: Prime Minister Yitzhak Rabin of Israel and President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt will meet next week, probably in Egypt, to explore ways to give the stalled Middle East peace talks a badly needed jump start, Israeli officials said today.   While it was not clear what the two men hoped to achieve, meetings between the Israeli and Egyptian leaders are hardly so common that that they can be dismissed as routine diplomatic maneuvers.
